to illustrate the detailed model training process of FedDD. As shown in Fig.
, the training process of FedDD contains seven main steps, which are elaborated as follows:

assigned to different clients in the next round.
Step 6. Global model and dropout rates download.
The server sends the dropout rates with the corresponding subnetwork to clients. In order to avoid overfitting of some local models, the server broadcasts the full model to all clients every

references: To show the effectiveness of our proposed scheme, we conduct two extensive evaluations: 1) 100 clients simulated in a lab server cluster. 2) a 10-client testbed deployed at 10 geo-distributed virtual machine (VM) instances rented from Alibaba Cloud.
In the simulation experiment, we consider image classification as the FL task and evaluate the performance of FedDD with three datasets: MNIST
. To simulate the model heterogeneity in real world, we carry out simulation experiments in two scenarios: 1)
Clients hold and train models with the same structure. 2)

Clients hold and train models with heterogeneous structures. In model-homogeneous scenarios, we perform experiments for MLP on MNIST, CNN1 on FMNIST and CNN2 on CIFAR10. The model configurations of this three models are shown in TABLE

. In model-heterogeneous scenarios, we perform experiments for five sub-models on CIFAR10 and each sub-model is hold by the same number of clients. To investigate how the degree of model heterogeneity affects the performance of FL, we set up two heterogeneous scenarios, namely model-heterogeneous-a and model-heterogeneous-b. Model-heterogeneous-a represents low model heterogeneity, while model-heterogeneous-b represents high model heterogeneity, as the differences among these five sub-models in model-heterogeneous-b setting are greater. The model configurations of model-heterogeneous-a and model-heterogeneous-b are shown in TABLE
in the separate supplementary file), respectively.

The factors that affect system heterogeneity include the computing performance of clientsâ€™ devices and network connection. Typical parameters of clientsâ€™ devices, network environment and other experiment setting are provided in Table
. All experiments were conducted using PyTorch version 1.10.1.

In the testbed experiment, we rent 11 geo-distributed virtual machine instances, including one parameter server and 10 clients, to constitute a real distributed FL system. These 11 virtual machine instances are located in Guangzhou, Shanghai, Zhangjiakou, Beijing, Nanjing, and Ulanqab, respectively. The specific configuration and geographical location are shown in Table
. Due to space limitation, we evaluate the performance of FedDD in testbed for CNN2 on CIFAR10 under Model-homogeneous setting. The hyperparameters

To simulate the data heterogeneity in real world, we set up three kinds of data heterogeneity, namely IID, Non-IID-a and Non-IID-b. In IID setting, all classes of data in the datasets are assigned to 100/10 clients with uniform distribution. In Non-IID-a setting, each client is assigned with different classes of data and the number of classes owned by each client is randomly generated from 2 to 10. In Non-IID-b setting, each client is assigned with three randomly selected classes.

references: 3) Model heterogeneity: Model heterogeneity refers to differences in size and structure of local models among clients. Traditional FL assumes that all the local models have the same structure. However, considering the heterogeneity of clientsâ€™ devices (storage size, battery capacity, etc.) and the complexity of its own tasks, it is more reasonable to allow clients to train local models of different sizes [18]. In our scheme, the parameter server holds and processes the global model, whose size is denoted as Uğ‘ˆU. Each client can deploy a sub-model (e.g., via model pruning) as the full local model that is suitable for itself before training, whose size is denoted as Unsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘›U_{n} and Uâ‰¥Unğ‘ˆsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘›U\geq U_{n} for all nğ‘›n. To simplify global aggregation, following the idea of [18], local sub-models have similar structure but can shrink their number of channels or neurons within the same layer. When local models of clients are heterogeneous, training losses are varied among heterogeneous models even when trained on the same dataset. Fig. 3 shows the training losses of 5 heterogeneous models (the model structures are showed in TABLE VI in Appendix A in the separate supplementary file) under IID setting. We can see that training loss of big model is lower than small model in the same round. If we directly compare the training losses of heterogeneous models, this leads to a misleading result: big models with lower losses will be assigned large dropout rates, which is detrimental to the convergence of global model. Therefore, we multiply training loss by a coefficient of normalized model size to rectify the naive training loss. The rectified training loss is denoted as UnUâ€‹lâ€‹oâ€‹sâ€‹sntsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘›ğ‘ˆğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğ‘¡\frac{U_{n}}{U}loss_{n}^{t}.
